hi welcome to another edition of in
conversation today I'm in conversation
with al fresco and I'm joined with Jorge
from al fresco welcome thank you very
much thanks for having us
let's just get right to it please tell
me a little bit about your company and
what you guys do
absolutely so my name is Jorge
peripatetic I work for al fresco I'm a
strategy solution strategy director a
first-class a company has been around as
an open-source company for a while
we help customers develop solutions fast
for digital transformation particularly
in the areas of information management
and process operations management
operations efficiency through that we
also support them in terms of governance
and compliance which is where gdpr
comes into the conversation but
ironically it's not just for compliance
purposes it effects all the parts of our
platform in terms of how do you manage
information how do you manage the
operations around gdpr and how do you
demonstrate your compliance to
regulators Wow so I mean that makes so
much sense having compliant security and
process together especially with gdpr
so what are some of the challenges that
you're hearing from your customers
around GDP our compliance conversation
varies depending on where in the journey
of the customers are I think most of the
customers are fairly comfortable that
they have ticked the right boxes to at
least demonstrate to a regulator that
they they have made an attempt at being
compliant where they are now is the next
stage of the journey to say how can we
stay compliant how can we stay on top of
it's going to be an ongoing problem it's
not a one-off tick box exercise we you
can't just write the policy and that's
done you need to be able to demonstrate
both to your customers enter your
regulators that is an ongoing commitment
and that you're honoring it different
customers in different parts of the
world and different industries have
different levels of maturity people who
had traditionally a very strong
data protection governance in their
country had a smaller leap to do to get
to DPR compliant the ones that came from
a more loose definition of data
protection and not enforced had a bigger
bigger journey to take them where they
are today I think they are all waiting
for the market to mature they're waiting
to see the first instances of how the
regulators will respond to incidents to
breaches how how much traffic they're
gonna get from requests from individuals
to manage their data it's all a whole
number of unknown so it's very difficult
to do a risk assess you of what has
priority from a GD P R so there's a
little bit of a wait and see game but at
the same time they have realized that
it's not something they can ignore and
it has starting to become part of their
their ecosystem in terms of how they
manage information that's very
consistent with what I've been seeing as
well and I agree that harmonization of
of all of these different privacy laws
and regulations and so on I think is
super important so that we have like
sort of one bar for everybody to try to
meet and in that point it's interesting
that you see now other areas outside
Europe starting to look at it and seeing
how they can get their data privacy to a
similar level of of support as they have
in Europe so it obviously resonated with
other a lot of other regimes as well
yeah and it makes so much sense because
you don't want privacy regulation to be
a drag on like an entire economy and so
making sure that you're meeting that
high bar will make it easier for you to
do business with companies in the EU or
at least
collect data for EU residents or
citizens and so in reality there's very
few organizations around the world from
you know the u.s. to China that don't
deal with EU citizens in EU citizens
data there's very few companies that are
really isolated within their own region
we have a globalization that's going on
so the question is how fast and how
aware these organizations outside Europe
are with a criticality of
managing European citizens data so I
think that will show probably the next
three to five years when we'll see the
regulated regulation starting to
challenge some of these companies to see
how they respond to it so how do you
think cloud helps these companies get to
GDP our compliance and that process that
you talked about how do how does cloud
help our organization as a whole has has
helped in two slightly different areas
one is they it takes the burden of
securing and protecting the data away it
allows you to handle that responsibility
to a cloud provider who can guarantee a
certain level of compliance around the
the preservation of the data the
protection of the data that the
availability of the data what it doesn't
do it doesn't absolve them from
responsibilities that are above that
level so as a company you still have to
look after what data you put in a cloud
system where did you get our data from
what capabilities do you have to respond
to requests around that data so the
cloud is not going to solve that for for
customers however it's one worry less
around the resources but what it also
allows them to do is as they get into
discovering the data sources that they
have in-house the which they have
ignored for a long time especially
around shared file systems and servers
that have been moved around through
acquisitions and nobody's around that
knows anymore what data is kept they
start to analyze that as I start to
analyze it they start adding value and
cleaning up the data that's no longer
there that's an opportunity for them to
transition that payload into a cloud
environment where it can be managed of
lower costs so it allows them to combine
the two processes and justifies the
investment into doing the cloud
transition that they have been wanting
to do but there was no core incentive or
core budget to do before gdpr
gives them another
step up the ladder of making the move to
the cloud so it helps with that
transition it helps minimize the costs
it doesn't absolve them of the
responsibility of actually doing to
